confession.devil_appearance: man in green with cloven feet
confession.seduction_context: She was lamenting her husband's illness, believing he would never recover, while having great difficulty guarding the herd. The devil promised to bring money but did not do so. She made the sign of the cross and he disappeared.

dispute over hay price and collection

testimony.threat_quote: if he did not pay he would see what happened

timeline.subject: Sibille femme Jean Vacquaire
timeline.details: Repeated story of meeting man in green; claimed she refused powder and made sign of cross

timeline.details: Substitut asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Sibille femme Jean Vacquaire
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture with thumbscrews; confessed to sabbat, killing animals, making people ill

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Demenge Jan Collatte and his wife Catherine of Deuxville
husband had let a garden to husband of accused, in return for free herding of his animals
Maurice Jan de Crion - killed his father

economic_context.details: Jean Vacquaire was a herdsman, and Sibille helped with the herd. Multiple disputes arose over payment for herding services, quality of herding (animals not taken out early enough, animals dying in herd), and rental arrangements (garden for herding services). Didier Malgray refused to lend her money and refused to rent her a barn. Didier Cognient had dispute over hay price. Sibille's husband lost the herd of Valhey when Jean de Crion as 'gouverneur de ville' deprived him of it. Economic hardship was a major theme - Didier Pinel claimed Sibille was 'cause de sa ruine totalle, dont il est presentement reduict en pauvreté' (cause of his total ruin, by which he is presently reduced to poverty) after losing 10 animals.

animal_predation: Wolves - multiple references to wolves strangling animals (Didier Malgray's cow strangled by wolf that Sibille predicted; Pieresson Roy's foal strangled with marks like wolf teeth though no wolf seen)
economic_hardship_indicators: Didier Pinel claimed Sibille was 'cause de sa ruine totalle, dont il est presentement reduict en pauvreté' (cause of his total ruin, reduced to poverty) after losing 10 animals
Multiple disputes over payment for herding services
Sibille tried to borrow money from Didier Malgray
Devil promised Sibille 3 or 4 francs but didn't deliver
Jean Vacquaire lost position as herdsman of Valhey
Animals dying of hunger because not taken out to pasture by 8am
Economic value of animals was significant - loss of multiple cows, horses, pigs represented major financial loss
religious_calendar_references: Whitsun - Pieresson Roy testified about events at Whitsun previous year

officials_named.name: Substitut for procureur général de Lorraine at Lunéville

prior_legal_disputes.description: Jean de Crion as 'gouverneur de ville' deprived Jean Vacquaire of the herd of Valhey (his position as herdsman)

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Imprisoned in 'fond du fosse' (bottom of pit/dungeon) which was so unpleasant she made false confession to be removed from it. Saw visions of lights like candles held by shadowy figure and figures like angels.

hearsay_chains.source: Maurice Jan de Crion, living at Valhey
hearsay_chains.content: she had killed his father 10 years before
he had lost a cow, and she had said this would not have happened if he had put it in herd with others

hearsay_chains.source: Jean de Crion of Valhey (on sickbed)
hearsay_chains.content: they would not drink together again, and that he was bewitched to death, because as gouverneur de ville he had deprived her husband of the herd of Valhey
Sibille asked how witness was, Demenge replied he was in danger of leaving wife and children, Sibille responded he would not die but would recover in 2 or 3 days

emotional_state_notes: Asked for priest to confess - later said this was false confession to be removed from bottom of dungeon
Initially confessed to meeting man in green, then retracted, saying it was untrue
Saw visions in prison - light in form of candles held by shadowy figure, figures like angels
During confrontations: made no reproaches, admitted some incidental details but denied all wrongdoing
Under torture: confessed but was warned not to accuse anyone wrongly or out of hatred, yet persisted in naming accomplices

third_parties.name: Maurice Jan de Crion

third_parties.name: Jean de Crion
third_parties.relationship_to_accused: as gouverneur de ville deprived her husband of herd of Valhey

third_parties.name: Jean Vacquaire

third_parties.name: Demenge Aulbry

third_parties.name: Jean Blaison
third_parties.context: Of Einville; Sibille claimed to have seen him at sabbat; Didier Cognient and other masons were working on his house when Sibille came and sat beside Cognient who fell ill

third_parties.name: niece of Sibille
third_parties.context: Sibille asked wife of Aubertin Tripa to be wet-nurse for her niece; refusal led to wife's illness

third_parties.name: son of Sibille (apprentice draper)

third_parties.name: Claudon (daughter of Sibille)
third_parties.context: Sibille confessed under torture that her daughter was a witch

third_parties.name: Messire Philbert
third_parties.context: Priest to whom Sibille initially confessed about man in green; she later said confession was false to get out of dungeon

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with 25 witnesses. Strong pattern of economic disputes (herding services, payment conflicts, rental disputes) underlying accusations. Reputation as witch stretched back 20 years to Valhey period. Confessed under torture to attending sabbat 4 times and named 7 accomplices including her own daughter. Notable features: predictions that came true (wolf strangling cow, recovery times from illness), supernatural knowledge (knowing about Blaisotte's frog symptoms), use of colored powders (black to harm, yellow to cure). Death sentence approved by Change de Nancy and Rémy (the famous witch-hunter). Geographic mobility evident in Sibille's employment history across 6 locations before marriage. Wolf predation was real problem in region. Many witnesses were married couples who corroborated each other's testimony.
